description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: The Government of Romania, through the Authority for the Digitization of Romania, and the non-governmental organization Code for Romania launched the online platform COVID-19 Official News (stirioficiale.ro) on Monday, 16.03.2020. The aim of this platform is to fight misinformation and fake news in order to rebuild trust with the state. The site only publishes reliable sources such as press releases from the Romanian government
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Voluntary/Recommended but No Penalties

description: On March 10th, 2020, the Romanian Ministry of Health announce that the study programs of exchange type of experience and internships in hospitals of students and pupils of post-secondary health schools are stopped, if they were not started before March 9 this year. Postsecondary internships for medical students and experience programs for healthcare and sanitation workers are also suspended if they were not started before March 9.

description: As a result of the current epidemiological context, the Ministry of Health announces to those interested that the examinations and competitions organized by the ministry are postponed. Thus, the exam for obtaining the title of specialist doctor - the session of March 19, 2020 and the competitions for the position in the health units are postponed until a date that will be announced later.

description:
On April 27th 2020, Romanian President Klaus Iohannis stated in a press release by the National Liberal Party that schools would remain closed for most students until the end of the school year- June 12th 2020. Online learning would continue for these students.

Students in the 8th and 12th grades could come into school from the period of June 2nd to June 12th to prepare for national exams for high school and university. Class sizes were restricted to a maximum of 10 students, and they would only be at school for 3 hours a day, maximum. Exams would continue with social distancing measures observed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: "The Romanian authorities are preparing for a scenario in which schools in the country will remain closed in September when the new school year will start. Courses could thus move online, and the local education system should be digitized by then, education minister Monica Anisie said in TV interviews over the weekend.  About 250,000 of the 3 million students enrolled in primary and secondary education in Romania don't have access to technology and can't participate in online courses, the education minister said at Digi24.  The Romanian authorities closed all schools and kindergartens in the country on March 11 to stop the spreading of the COVID-19 epidemic. The decision was enforced before the state of emergency was decreed in the country, on March 16.  On April 27, president Klaus Iohannis announced that schools would remain closed in Romania until the end of the school year."

description: Romanian schools scheduled to re-open from 14th September, 2020. Schools can use three learning models when the new school year starts, depending on each locality's coronavirus situation. The three scenarios are: in-person classes, the hybrid model (alternating virtual learning and in-class learning), and online/at-home only learning.

description: Romanian Ministry of Education and Research announced on 22nd of October, 2020, that 2401 education units are listed to work in red scenario (Scenario 3), involving the participation only in online activities. 4891 education units are listed in Scenario 2, meaning partial return (by rotation) in compliance with all rules of protection and 10364 in Scenario 1 (daily participation in compliance with all health protection rules).  According to the Order of the Minister of Education and Research and the Minister of Health 5487/1494/01.09.2020, one of the three operating scenarios is the cumulative incidence rate, respectively the total number of new cases in the last 14 days compared to 1000 inhabitants.

description: According to the Romanian ministerial order 5972/8.11.20, starting on 9.11.20, the teaching activities that require the physical presence of preschoolers and students in preschool, primary, secondary, high school and post-secondary education units are suspended for a period of 30 days. The teaching activities will be carried out online, according to the Framework Methodology on conducting teaching activities through technology and the Internet, as well as for the processing of personal data, approved by order of the Ministry of Education and Research 5545/2020.

description: Schools in Romania will reopen from 8-Feb-21 but under different scenarios according to their local epidemiological situations. Under the green scenario, which corresponds to an infection rate of under 1.5 per 1,000 inhabitants (over a 14-day period), all students return to school. In the yellow scenario (infection rate of between 1.5 and 3), only kindergarten and primary school (I-IV grades) pupils return to school together with students in the eighth and twelfth grades, who have to prepare for the national exams. In the red scenario (infection rate of over 3), only kindergartens and primary schools will stay open. Localities with infection rates of over 6 per 1,000 residents will remain under lockdown, with schools closed, according to the plan announced by president Iohannis.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Other Health Monitoring
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: According to the Romanian ministerial order no.3.235/93/04.02.2021, depending on the incidence rate by localities, the activity of the educational units will be organized, starting with 8th of February, in three scenarios: a) Physical presence for all categories, if the cumulative incidence in the last 14 days in the locality is less or equal to 1/1000 people; b) physical presence for preschool, primary, 8th, 12th and 13th classes, and online presence for the other classes, for a incidence less or equal with 3/1000; c) Online presence for all categories, except preschool and primary units, if incidence is higher than 3/1000.

description: On May 12, 2021, national assessments in Romania began for grades 2, 4 and 6 for the school year 2020-2021. All tests take place with physical presence, regardless of the scenarios in which the schools are located.  The rooms in which these assessments are held are, as a rule, those in which students carry out their activities on a regular basis. These are adapted in advance, as appropriate, according to the planned test, by eliminating any teaching materials that could influence students.

description:
Romania imposed a curfew starting on the 21st of March 2020. 
In the time interval 22.00 - 06.00, the movement of persons outside the household is allowed only for medical purposes, work, acquiring goods to cover basic needs- including those of pets, caring for a child/elderly person, short physical activity trips including walking pets.

In order to verify the reason for traveling in the professional interest, the persons are obliged to present, at the request of the competent authorities staff, the service card, the certificate issued by the employer or a declaration on their own responsibility or a declaration on their own responsibility, completed in advance.

The declaration on one's own responsibility must include the name and surname, date of birth, residential address/ place of professional activity, reason for travel, date of completion and signature.

The exceptions to these provisions are the personnel within the Presidential Administration, the Romanian Parliament, the Romanian Government, the Public Ministry, the institutions of the national defense system, public order and national security, the diplomatic corps and the personnel providing public utility services.
type_sub_cat: No the curfew times are always the same regardless of the day of the week
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time)

description: On March 24, 2020, Romania imposed a curfew on all over 65 year olds, who are only allowed to leave home between 11:00am and 1:00pm for medical treatments, providing goods that cover the basic needs of persons and pets, and moving for justified reasons, such as caring for a minor, assisting other elderly, sick or disabled people, or in case of death of a family member.

compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
On March 24, 2020, Romania imposed a curfew on all over 65-year-olds, who are only allowed to leave home between 11:00am and 1:00pm for medical treatments, providing goods that cover the basic needs of persons and pets, and moving for justified reasons, such as caring for a minor, assisting other elderly, sick or disabled people, or in case of death of a family member.
 UPDATE: On April 27, 2020, Romania  imposed a curfew on all over 65-year-olds, who are only allowed to leave home between 7:00am and 11:00am, and 7:00pm and 10:00pm for provision of goods that cover the basic needs of persons and pets, and for justified reasons, such as caring for a minor, assisting other elderly, sick or disabled people, or in case of death of a family member. Travel for medical treatments, professional activities, and agricultural purposes are allowed irrespective of the time slots.

description: On November 5, 2020, Romania banned "the movement of persons outside the home / household between 23.00 - 05.00" with the exemption of traveling for professional interests, medical assistance, and justified reasons, such as caring for / accompanying the child, assisting the elderly, sick or disabled or the death of a family member. UPDATE: From March 25, 2021, curfew times are adapted: Where the cumulative 14-days incidence is over 4 and under or equal to 7.5 / 1000 residents, there is a curfew on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays between 8 pm and 5 am, with the same exemptions applying. Where the cumulative 14-days incidence is over 7.5 / 1000 residents, there is a daily curfew between 8 pm and 5 am, with the same exemptions applying. From March 27, 6 pm, to March 28, 10 pm, curfews are suspended for the purpose of participating in Passover festivities. From April 3, 8 pm, to April 4, 2 am, curfews are suspended for the purpose of participating in worship services.

description:
Romania, May 15, 2021:
The Romanian government imposes a curfew on regions where the cumulative 14-days incidence is over 4 and under or equal to 7.5 / 1000 residents which applies on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays between 8 pm and 5 am. Exceptions exist Where the cumulative 14-days incidence is over 7.5 / 1000 residents, there is a daily curfew between 8 pm and 5 am, with the same exemptions applying. On May 13 between 2 and 5 am, the curfew is suspended for the purpose of participating in Ramazan Bayram festivities.
The policy is slated to end on June 11.

description: Entry is denied to maritime crew arriving into Romanian seaports by boat from high risk (Red/Yellow zone) areas if they do not have the protective equipment, or if their vessel has in the last 14 days docked in a port located in a Red/Yellow risk area. Additionally, vessels are forbidden to dock in the following ports on the Danube River if they have in the last 14 days docked in a port port located in a Red/Yellow risk area: 1. Sulina port for vessels coming from Black Sea2. Danube River mile 44 for vessels coming from Bastroe.

description: Starting from May 4, 2002, drivers of lorries with a maximum authorized capacity of more than 2.4 tonnes who do not have symptoms associated with COVID-19 shall complete a solemn declaration on entry into Romania, a specimen of which has been established by the Ministry of Transport, Infrastructure and Communications, specifying the place where they will be located so that they can be contacted in the period between shifts.  They are not subject to domestic isolation   quarantine measures provided that the employer has provided them with individual protective measures against COVID-19

description:
Romania, February 12, 2021:
The National Committee for Emergency Situations declares that all persons arriving in Romania from countries/areas/territories with a "high epidemiological risk" shall present a certificate of a negative RT-PCR test for SARS-CoV-2 carried out no longer than 72 hours before the date of entry into the country. The countries/areas/territories currently affected by this measure can be found in the source document "Lista tarilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 6 din 04.02.2021 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Exempted from this measure are, among other things, children under 3 years of age and vaccinated people (see article 1 of the source document "HOTĂRÂRE nr. 7 din 04.02.2021"). The ending of this policy is indefinite.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description: From the 19th of June 2020, the Ministry of Transport, Infrastructure and Communications in Romania is launching an application in which travellers entering Henri Coanda Airport, Bucharest have to fill out a questionnaire. This includes contact details and residence of isolation- if necessary. Travellers must then isolate for 10 days. This is targeted towards people travelling from areas of high epidemiological risk, but not to those with similar or less infection rates than Romania. After 10 days of quarantine, travellers are free to leave isolation.
type_sub_cat: A snapshot of a person’s health at a given point in time

description: On the 21st of January 2020, the Technical-Scientific Support Group for the Management of Highly Contagious Diseases in Romania decided with the Ministry of Internal Affairs to order 1,750,000 protective resources, including PPE, single use gloves and protective masks. They also allocated 110 isolation rooms with negative pressure, 200 cardio respirator machines- 3 sets for the 57 emergency hospitals plus 9 Regional Centres of Infectious diseases, and 2 reserves. They also ordered 150 sets of filters for the isolated rooms, 9000 litres of disinfectant TP1, 9000 litres of TP 2, 5,100 kg of disinfectant for semicritical surfaces, and 5,100 kg of disinfectant for noncritical surfaces.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Voluntary/Recommended but No Penalties

They also ordered 150 sets of filters for the isolated rooms, 9000 litres of disinfectant TP1, 9000 litres of TP 2, 5,100 kg of disinfectant for semicritical surfaces, and 5,100 kg of disinfectant for noncritical surfaces.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Voluntary/Recommended but No Penalties
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 18, 2020, Romania banned the export of relevant medical devices and sanitary materials that "ensure the prevention and treatment of COVID-19 associated diseases, as well as of the drugs included in the National Catalog of the prices of authorized medical products for marketing in Romania."
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time)

description: On March 31, 2020, Romania asked all local authorities to place disinfectant solutions in all housing societies and to disinfect elevators, stairwells and other common areas.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time)

description: On March 31, 2020, Romania empowered the Center for Medical-Military Scientific Research, the Center for CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Scientific), Scientific Research for Defense and Ecology, the Agency for  Research of Military Technique and Technologies and the National Institute for Medical-Military Research and Development "Cantacuzino" to approve/authorize medical materials, components, equipment and devices necessary for the prevention and control of the spread, as well as for the treatment of the infection with the SARS-CoV-2 virus, and also biocides.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time)

description:
Romania, July 22, 2020:
The Department for Emergency Situations imposes a zonal quarantine on the locality of Gornet, municipality of Gornet, county of Prahova starting at 10 pm, and on the locality of Cartojani, municipality of Roata de Jos, county of Giurgiu starting at 5 pm. Exceptions for entering/exiting these localities exist. Policies are slated to end after 14 days.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On March 25, 2020, Romania issued a military ordinance, to enforce a lockdown, as all citizens were forbidden from traveling outside of their homes unless it is for professional purposes or the purchase of essential goods (with several other smaller exceptions).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time)

description:
Romania, March 30, 2020:
The Ministry of Internal Affairs imposes a zonal quarantine on the municipality of Suceava and the surrounding area consisting of the following eight municipalities: Adâncata, Salcea, Ipotești, Bosanci, Moara, Șcheia, Pătrăuți and Mitocu Dragomirnei. Exceptions for entering/exiting this locality exist. Reuters: "The quarantine will last until mid-April at the end of the 30-day emergency period". The state of emergency is slated to end on April 15.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Suceava; Adâncata; Salcea; Ipotești; Bosanci; Moara; Șcheia; Pătrăuți; Mitocu Dragomirnei.
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Romania issued a military ordinance, to enforce a lockdown, as all citizens were forbidden from traveling outside of their homes unless it is for professional purposes or the purchase of essential goods (with several other smaller exceptions). UPDATE: From May 15th 2020, Romania went from a state of emergency to a state of alert, and self-declaration forms will no longer be needed to leave the house

description: On February 24, Romania announced that any visitors from northern Italy would be placed in isolation for 14 days.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time)

description:
Romania, February 24, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: The Chinese provinces of Hubei (including the cities of Hubei and Wuhan) and Zhejiang (explicitly the cities of Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou); the Lombardy and Veneto regions in Italy (explicitly the localities of Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano); Cumiana in the Italian Piedmont region. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (institutionalized quarantine). Those from other places in mainland China and the Lombardy and Veneto regions need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The policy has no explicit end date.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou (Zhejiang); Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano (Lombardy/Veneto); Cumiana (Piedmont)
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

Romania, February 1, 2020:
The Ministry of Internal Affairs enacts that all travellers from China are obliged to quarantine themselves for 14 days upon arrival. Negative PCR tests may reduce the duration of isolation. The policy has no explicit end date. UPDATE: From February 24, individuals from additional countries/regions are subject to quarantine measures. The list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures is now provided for and regularly updated by the Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT).

description:
Romania, February 28, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: The Chinese provinces of Hubei (including the cities of Hubei and Wuhan) and Zhejiang (explicitly the cities of Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou); the Lombardy and Veneto regions in Italy (explicitly the localities of Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano). All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (institutionalized quarantine). Those from other places in mainland China and the Lombardy and Veneto regions need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The policy has no explicit end date.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou (Zhejiang); Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano (Lombardy/Veneto)
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description:
Romania, March 2, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: The Chinese provinces of Hubei (including the cities of Hubei and Wuhan) and Zhejiang (explicitly the cities of Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou); the Lombardy and Veneto regions in Italy (explicitly the localities of Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano); the South Korean localities of Daegu and Cheongdo. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (red zone). The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.

description:
Romania, March 8, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: The Chinese province of Hubei; the Italian regions of Lombardia, Veneto (namely Vo Euganeo, Venezia, Padova and Treviso), Emilia-Romagna (namely Modena, Parma, Piacenza, Reggio
Emilia and Rimini), Marche (namely Pesaro e Urbino), Piemont (namely Asti, Alessandria, Novara, Verbano-CusioOssola, Vercelli); the South Korean city of Daegu and county of Cheongdo. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (red zone). Additionally, those from the Heinsberg District in North Rhine-Westphalia (Germany), Iran as well as other places in South Korea, mainland China and Italy need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)

description:
Romania, March 2, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. These include: The Chinese provinces of Hubei (including the cities of Hubei and Wuhan) and Zhejiang (explicitly the cities of Wenzhou, Hangzhou, Ningbo and Taizhou); the Lombardy and Veneto regions in Italy (explicitly the localities of Vo Euganeo, Codogno, Castiglione d'Adda, Casarpusterlengo, Fombio, Maleo, Somaglia, Bertonico, Terranova dei Passerini, Castelgerundo and San Fiorano); the South Korean localities of Daegu and Cheongdo. All travellers from these places are quarantined for 14 days upon arrival in spaces specially designed for this purpose (red zone). Additionally, those from the Italian Emilia-Romagna region and Iran as well as other places in South Korea, mainland China and the Lombardy and Veneto regions need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: From March 8, the red zone countries/regions are:

- Hubei Province (including Wuhan City) (China)
- Lombardy region (Italy)
- Vo Euganeo , Venezia, Padova, Treviso (Veneto region - Italy)
- Modena, Parma, Piacenza, Reggio Emilia, Rimini (Emilia-Romagna region - Italy)
- Pesaro e Urbino (Marche region - Italy)
- Asti, Alessandria, Novara, Verbano-CusioOssola, Vercelli (Piedmont Region - Italy)
- Daegu and Cheongdo (Gyeongsangbuk-do)

... the yellow zone countries/regions are:

- other provinces and cities in mainland China
- all other regions and localities in Italy
- other counties and localities in South Korea
- the whole of Iran
- the Heinsberg District in North Rhine-Westphalia (Germany)
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_province: China: Hubei,Zhejiang; Italy: Emilia-Romagna,Lombardy,Veneto; South Korea: Gyeongsangbuk-do

Additionally, those from Iran as well as other places in South Korea, mainland China, France, Germany and Spain need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.

description:
Romania, March 27, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) declares that, should HCW [health-care workers; W.H.] come into contact with confirmed cases and they do not present with symptoms, they are asked to self-isolate at home [for 14 days; W.H.] without a test. Diagnostic test will be administered should symptoms appear. The ending of this recommendation is indefinite.

description:
Romania, May 15, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, all countries in the world are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: From June 15, individuals from the following countries may enter Romania without the need for quarantining if they are asymptomatic (green zone countries): Austria, Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Cyprus, Croatia, Switzerland, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Malta, Norway, Slovakia, Slovenia, Hungary.
Also, some new exceptions are added according to article 1, numbers 3 and 4 of the source document "ORDIN nr. 1.080 din 12 iunie 2020".

Currently, all countries in the world are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: From July 7, additional countries are labelled as green zone countries. The current green zone countries can be found in the source document.

target_geog_level: All countries

description: From 11th August 2020, travellers from Spain will be placed in a 14 day quarantine in Romania. The place of quarantine will either be the person's home, at a location declared by him or, as the case may be, in a special space designated by the authorities. Quarantine is recommended to all people who live at the same address.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines

Romania, December 21, 2020:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Czech Republic, Luxembourg, French Polynesia, Slovenia, Armenia, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Croatia, Georgia, Austria, Montenegro, San Marino, Portugal, Northern Macedonia, Jordan, Hungary, Bulgaria, Lithuania, Denmark, Serbia, the US, Curaçao, Sweden, Belize, Jersey, Panama, Palestine, Azerbaijan, Puerto Rico, Netherlands, Cyprus, Slovakia, Turkey, Moldavia, Latvia, Estonia, UK and Northern Ireland. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On December 25, French Polynesia, Austria, Armenia, Jordan are removed from the list of yellow zone countries while Gibraltar, Sint Maarten and South Africa are added.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Israel, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, Puerto Rico, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Turks and Caicos Islands, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, Lebanon, St. Lucia, Albania, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, Maldives, Peru, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Hungary, Jordan, Palestine, Bulgaria, Kosovo, Bonaire, Saint Eustatius and Saba, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Isle of Man, Liechtenstein, Republic of Moldova. Individuals from these countries are to be quarantined for 14 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_country: Albania,Andorra,Austria,Bahrain,Belgium,Bosnia and Herzegovina,Brazil,Bulgaria,Chile,Cyprus,Czechia,Estonia,France,Hungary,Israel,Italy,Jordan,Kosovo,Kuwait,Latvia,Lebanon,Liechtenstein,Lithuania,Luxembourg,Maldives,Malta,Moldova,Monaco,Montenegro,Netherlands,North Macedonia,Other (please specify below),Palestine,Peru,Poland,Saint Lucia,San Marino,Serbia,Seychelles,Slovakia,Slovenia,South Africa,Spain,Sweden,United Arab Emirates,United Kingdom,Uruguay
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
Romania, March 6, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Israel, Italy, Latvia, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, Puerto Rico, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Turks and Caicos Islands, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, United States of America, Lebanon, St. Lucia, Albania, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, Maldives, Peru, Dominican Republic, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Qatar, Hungary, Antigua and Barbuda, Barbados, Jordan, Palestine, Bulgaria, Kosovo and Paraguay. Individuals from these countries with a negative RT-PCR test, carried out no more than 72 hours before boarding or entering the national territory, are to be quarantined for 10 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On March 14, 2021, Antigua and Barbuda, Barbados, Paraguay, Qatar and the US are removed from the list of yellow zone countries while Bonaire, Saint Eustatius and Saba, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Isle of Man and Liechtenstein are added.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_country: Albania,Andorra,Antigua and Barbuda,Austria,Bahrain,Barbados,Belgium,Brazil,Bulgaria,Chile,Cyprus,Czechia,Estonia,France,Hungary,Israel,Italy,Jordan,Kosovo,Kuwait,Latvia,Lebanon,Lithuania,Luxembourg,Maldives,Malta,Moldova,Monaco,Montenegro,Netherlands,North Macedonia,Other (please specify below),Palestine,Paraguay,Peru,Poland,Qatar,Saint Lucia,San Marino,Serbia,Seychelles,Slovakia,Slovenia,South Africa,Spain,Sweden,United Arab Emirates,United Kingdom,United States,Uruguay

Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Italy, Latvia, Luxembourg, Malta, Monaco, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, San Marino, Serbia, Seychelles, Slovakia, Slovenia South Africa, Sweden, Lebanon, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Hungary, Jordan, Palestine, Bulgaria, Kosovo, Bonaire, Saint Eustatius and Saba, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Moldova, Territory of Wallis and Futuna Islands, Curaçao and Paraguay. Individuals from these countries with a negative RT-PCR test, carried out no more than 72 hours before boarding or entering the national territory, are to be quarantined for 10 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On April 2, 2021, Latvia, Malta and Slovacia are removed from the list of yellow zone countries while Armenia, Bermuda, Croatia, Turkey and Ukraine are added.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Romania, May 10, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries are labelled as yellow zone countries, which means that those arriving from these countries need to enter self-isolation for 14 days upon arrival: Andorra, Aruba, Austria, Brazil, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Estonia, France, Italy, Luxembourg, Montenegro, Netherlands, Poland, Serbia, Seychelles, Slovenia South Africa, Sweden, Lebanon, Bahrain, Chile, Belgium, Uruguay, North Macedonia, Kuweit, Hungary, Jordan, Bulgaria, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Curaçao, Armenia, Bermuda, Croatia, Turkey, Ukraine, Puerto Rico, Argentina, Azerbaidjan, Canada, Cape Verde, Columbia, Costa Rica, Switzerland, Georgia, Germany, Greece, Iran, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Maldives, Mongolia, Oman, Paraguay, Peru, Qatar, US, Anguilla, Bahamas, Belarus, Bolivia, Denmark, Ecuador, United Arab Emirates, Guyana, India, Irak, Kazahstan, Monaco, Nepal, Palestina, Spain, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago and Tunisia. Individuals from these countries with a negative RT-PCR test, carried out no more than 72 hours before boarding or entering the national territory, are to be quarantined for 10 days. Exceptions exist. Institutionalized quarantine is still available if needed. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On May 14, 2021, countries are again classified into red zone (where the cumulative incidence rate of new cases of illness in the last 14 days per 1,000 inhabitants is greater than or equal to 3 per 1,000 inhabitants), yellow zone (...between 1,5 and 3 per 1 000 inhabitants) and green zone (...less than or equal to 1.5) countries. For persons arriving from green zone countries, no quarantine measures shall be imposed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries/regions are labelled as red zone countries: Argentina, Bahrain, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Columbia, Costa Rica, India, Kuwait, Maldives, Mongolia, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Paraguay, Seychelles, South Africa, Suriname, Trinidad and Tobago, United Kingdom, United States Virgin Islands, Uruguay. The following countries/regions are labelled as yellow zone countries: Botswana, Cape Verde, Georgia, Guyana, Malaysia, Panama, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Sint Maarten, Sri Lanka, Tunisia, United Arab Emirates. Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On June 25, 2021, the list of red and yellow zone countries was updated.

The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. Currently, the following countries/regions are labelled as red zone countries: Andorra, Argentina, Botswana, Brazil, British Virgin Islands, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Cyprus, Faroe Islands, Fiji, Georgia, Gibraltar, India, Iran, Iraq, Isle of Man, Jersey, Kazakhstan, Kuwait, Libya, Malaysia, Malta, Mongolia, Namibia, Nepal, Netherlands, Panama, Portugal, Seychelles, South Africa, Spain, Suriname, Tunisia, United Kingdom. The following countries/regions are labelled as yellow zone countries: Bahamas, Curaçao, Denmark, Eswatini, Greece, Guatemala, Indonesia, Ireland, Kyrgyzstan, Luxembourg, Maldives, Monaco, Oman, Paraguay, Russian Federation, Thailand, Trinidad and Tobago, United Arab Emirates, United States Virgin Islands, Uruguay, Zimbabwe. Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_country: Andorra,Argentina,Bahamas,Botswana,Brazil,Colombia,Costa Rica,Cuba,Cyprus,Denmark,Eswatini,Fiji,Georgia,Greece,Guatemala,India,Indonesia,Iran,Iraq,Ireland,Kazakhstan,Kuwait,Kyrgyzstan,Libya,Luxembourg,Malaysia,Maldives,Malta,Monaco,Mongolia,Namibia,Nepal,Netherlands,Oman,Other (please specify below),Panama,Paraguay,Portugal,Russia,Seychelles,South Africa,Spain,Suriname,Thailand,Trinidad and Tobago,Tunisia,United Arab Emirates,United Kingdom,Uruguay,Zimbabwe

The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista țărilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 97 din 04.11.2021 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On November 14, 2021, the list of red and yellow zone countries was updated.

description:
Romania, December 10, 2021:
The Romanian National Emergency Committee enacts that individuals entering Romania from EU countries, EEA countries and Switzerland are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are not tested negative for, not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19. Individuals entering Romania from third-party countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they can't submit a negative test result upon arrival. The quarantine duration may be shortened to 10 days. In some cases, individuals are exempted from the quarantine obligation. The policy ends on January 8, 2022. Also, the Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

Also, the Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Romania, December 5, 2021:
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Individuals from red and yellow zone countries/regions need to go into self or institutionalized quarantine for 14 days. Red and yellow zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. Quarantine measures do not apply to green zone countries/regions. The ending of this policy depends on decreasing infection transmission rates. UPDATE: On December 10, 2021, persons arriving from Member States of the European Union, the European Economic Area or the Swiss Confederation are subject to different quarantine obligations compared to those from third-party countries. Third country nationals are to be quarantined if they do not submit a negative result of an RT-PCR test for COVID-19 carried out not more than 48 hours before boarding (for those travelling by public transport) or entering the national territory (for those travelling by their own means). Individuals from the EU, the EEA or Switzerland can also avert to be quarantined if they are vaccinated against or have recovered from COVID-19.

description:
Romania, December 10, 2021:
The Romanian National Emergency Committee enacts that individuals entering Romania from EU countries, EEA countries and Switzerland are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are not tested negative for, not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19. Individuals entering Romania from third-party countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they can't submit a negative test result upon arrival. The quarantine duration may be shortened to 10 days. In some cases, individuals are exempted from the quarantine obligation. The policy ends on January 8, 2022. Also, the Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista cu clasificarea țărilor/teritoriilor în funcție de rata de incidență cumulată". Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions. UPDATE: Based on DECISION no. 113 of 10.12.2021, individuals from third countries are to be quarantined for 14 days if they are tested positive for COVID-19 and are not vaccinated against or have not recovered from it. These individuals, if they are not vaccinated against or have not recovered from COVID-19, are to be quarantined for 10 days if they are tested negative for COVID-19. If vaccinated or recovered, they are to be quarantined for 10 days if they are tested positive for COVID-19.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

Also, the Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions affected by quarantine measures. The countries/regions labelled as red and yellow zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista țărilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 115 din 17.12.2021 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Some quarantine measures differ between yellow and red zone countries/regions. UPDATE: From December 23, 2021, additional exceptions to the quarantine obligation are introduced according to the source document.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Romania, January 9, 2022:
The National Emergency Committee declares that persons arriving in Romania from
countries/territories at epidemiological risk as well as direct contacts of confirmed persons are to be quarantined upon arrival:
a) 10 days for unvaccinated persons or persons who are not in the period between
the 11th to the 180th day after the date of confirmation of SARS-CoV-2 infection;
b) 5 days for vaccinated persons for whom 10 days have passed since the completion of
the vaccination scheme, and for persons who have been confirmed for SARS-CoV-2 infection SARS-CoV-2 virus between the 11th and the 180th day before the date of entry into the country or contact with the infected person. 
The Romanian National Institute of Public Health / National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT) provides a list of countries/regions at epidemiological risk. The countries/regions labelled as red, yellow and green zone countries/regions can be found in the source document "Lista țărilor/zonelor cu risc epidemiologic ridicat, conform Hotărârii nr. 2 din 07.01.2022 a Comitetului Național pentru Situații de Urgență". Red, yellow and green zone countries/regions differ in how exceptions apply. The end of this policy isn't mentioned.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry),Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
Romania, February 1, 2022:
The National Emergency Committee declares that those arriving in Romania who are not vaccinated against, have not recovered from or have not tested negative for SARS-CoV-2, are to be quarantined for 5 days upon arrival (for details, see article 1 of the source document "HOTĂRÂREA nr. 6 din 31.01.2022"). Also, quarantine is to be established for a period of 5 days for contacts of a person confirmed to be infected with SARS-CoV-2. Exceptions exist. The policy's end date isn't mentioned.

description: From May 15th 2020 in Romania, private businesses/ economic operators are obliged to ensure that employers can work from home. If the work can not be performed from home then employers must not allow the access of the persons whose body temperature, measured at the entrance to the enclosure exceeds 37.3 degrees. Employers must enforce mandatory disinfection of hands before entering work spaces, and disinfection of surfaces.

description:
Romania banned all mass gatherings of over 100 people from the 11th March 2020 until the 31st of March 2020, with the possibility of prolonging. This includes gatherings for sport, religious, scientific or leisure events. Indoor spaces such as theatres and cinemas were closed, but not shopping malls. 

This decision was announced by the head of the Department of Emergency Situations (DSU), Raed Arafat and Health Minister Nelu Tataru.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description:
Romania banned all mass gatherings of over 100 people from the 11th March 2020 until the 31st of March 2020, with the possibility of prolonging. This includes gatherings for sport, religious, scientific or leisure events. Indoor spaces such as theatres and cinemas were closed, but not shopping malls. 

This decision was announced by the head of the Department of Emergency Situations (DSU), Raed Arafat and Health Minister Nelu Tataru.

On March 14th 2020, gatherings of more than 50 people were banned. UPDATE: The original policy restricted gatherings up to 100 people. The new policy restricts gatherings up to 50.

For events with a maximum of 100 people, organizers must take action to enforce a distance of at least 1 meter between participants.

description: The outdoor cultural events (concerts) are allowed, but only if they respect of safety rules and sports competitions can be organized outdoors or at indoor pools but without spectators due to the extended state of alert by the Romanian government from August 16, 2020, to September 15, 2020. UPDATE: UPDATE: The state of alert on the entire territory of Romania is extended by 30 days until October 15. Private events in open spaces up to a maximum of 100 people are allowed, provided the observance of physical distancing applies. The organization of outdoor public meetings, rallies and demonstrations with a maximum number of 100 participants and provided compliance with the following measures: Mask mearing by all participants as to cover the nose and mouth; Mandatory disinfection of the hands, for all the persons who arrive in the space where they are conducts the rally or demonstration; Maintaining the physical distance of at least 1 meter between the participants and ensuring an area of minimum 4 sqm / person where possible; Disinfection of the hands of the persons who distribute any materials during the rally or demonstration.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions

compliance: Mandatory with Fines

description: Authorities of Romanian counties, Hunedoara, Bacău and Lași impose restrictions of mass gatherings in the Horeca area, after the end of the local elections. In Hunedoara county, in 12 localities, the operation of restaurants and bars is no longer allowed. In Bacău county, similar measures were taken in several localities, as well as in Iași county. The restrictions come in the context in which in several localities in the counties the infection rate of 1.5 / 1000 inhabitants has been exceeded in the last two weeks. The measures were taken at the central level and cover the whole country. Additionally, mass gathering events, such as concerts, cultural events, and gambling activities were either prohibited or subjected to curfew (shortened business hours).
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
On October 5, 2020, Romania announced that "the organization of religious holidays is allowed only with the participation of persons who have their domicile or residence in the locality where the activity takes place, without the participation of persons / pilgrims from other localities."

CNSU decided to limit the attendance to religious events and celebrations amid growing COVID-19 infection cases. Only locals will be allowed to attend religious events held in Romanian localities. This includes the banning of religious pilgrimages. This decision comes prior to the largest pilgrimage in Romania to Lasi which will begin 08-Oct and reach its peak at 14-Oct. Currently no restrictions on free movement in Romania.

description: The organization and outdoor performance of shows, concerts, public and private festivals or other cultural events is allowed in counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is less than or equal to 1.5/1,000 inhabitants.     Events are limited to 300 spectators with seats located at a distance of at least 2 meters apart. Protective masks are also required.    Activities are prohibited in counties/localities where the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is higher than 1.5/1,000 inhabitants.    Currently the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is higher than 1.5/1,000 occupants in Timis, Maramures, Cluj, Brasov, Ilfov, Bucharest, Alba, Hunedoara, Satu Mare, Sibiu, Salaj, and Gorj counties.

description: Authorities in Romania have eased several domestic COVID-19-related restrictions on June 1, 2021. Outdoor gatherings are limited to 1,000 persons. Limitations on attendance at indoor gatherings including concerts, weddings and other cultural, leisure, or religious activities, have been lifted provided all the attendees are vaccinated. Gyms, fitness centres, museums, public swimming pools, and restaurants may operate at 70 per cent capacity.   Private events (weddings, baptisms, and birthdays) may accommodate a maximum of 70 guests outdoor, 50 guests indoor, or unlimited guests if those attending are all vaccinated.

description: Due to the recent decrease in COVID-19 cases, the Government of Romania announced new relaxation measures.  The new restrictions generally increase capacity and participant limits for public and private events, restaurants and resorts, and other entertainment activities.  In general, events and venues may accommodate clients at full capacity if all participants are vaccinated.  Otherwise, the measures reflect a gradual relaxation of restrictions. They include the following:  Private events (weddings, baptisms, and birthdays) may accommodate a maximum of 70 guests outdoor, 50 guests indoor, or unlimited guests if those attending are all vaccinated.  Restaurants and cafés may open between 0500-2400 at 70% capacity or full capacity if all guests are vaccinated.  Gyms and fitness facilities may open at 70% capacity with seven meters distance between clients or full capacity if all clients are vaccinated.  In certain localities with low incident rates, masks may not be required.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: All Recreational or commercial events allowed to occur with conditions
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied)

description: From May 15th 2020 in Romania, private businesses/ economic operators are obliged to ensure that employers can work from home. Local authorities may also oblige individuals from 5 upwards to wear a face mask in certain outdoor public spaces, such as markets, at certain time intervals. The policy is in place for the duration of the state of alert.

description:
Romania, September 15, 2020:
The Government of Romania enacts that individuals have to wear a face mask in commercial spaces, public transport, at work and in other enclosed spaces. Local authorities may also oblige individuals from 5 upwards to wear a face mask in certain outdoor public spaces, such as markets, at certain time intervals. Face covering measures now also explicitly apply to candidates and campaign teams during events/meetings/actions related to election campaigns and to the participants in the electoral process as per article 4, section 1, number 2 of the source document.
